jurisdiction.title: Holy Spirit Catholic School Division - Alberta, Canada

781FCC617F444D1DB822CB53C21A30B9.description: Discuss how storytelling can contribute to personal well-being.

D30D2E4EB05B463FB99A9FC517B19187.description: Culture can be revealed through First Nations, Metis, and Inuit storytelling.

71C7CD1FF43A4377B2F91FC2D5EEB497.description: Drama from various times and places can be representative of a culture

5AA73C42BB51451E8A2987714A2C7E41.description: Culture is what people do and a way of thinking.

7877254EE714431C94BCB0109C6E997B.description: First Nations, Metis, and Inuit storytelling is holistic in nature and can have individual and collective benefits, including social well-being physical health spiritual connection emotional and mental well-being intellectual development

503C9FE37DA64AFC824E846AE9B3119B.description: Storytelling can reflect cultural beliefs history relationship ways of life intergenerational knowledge

620D3ABC03CA4BB19155CD44A27DD0C0.description: First Nations, Metis, and Inuit storytelling includes oral traditions that can be passed on between and among individuals and communities with proper protocol.

32A43C057367407CBC7092594E2AE563.description: First Nations, Metis, and Inuit communities have specific protocols related to how, when, or with whom stories are shared

E5F33F6B928D48688979F89D9E1094ED.description: Dramatic plays included topics that were important to the people of ancient Greece and part of community life

C403A0321DEE4CE29BD149FDD40E921F.description: The culture of Greek theatre was known for outdoor performances the use of masks of exaggerated expressions two types of plays called comedy and tragedy a chorus of actors who spoke and sung in unison

6B9B9F6284CB4AECB4B8FA974CD90A88.description: Theatre in ancient Greece evolved from religious rituals.

F6BB31AE859541679791363BF2023536.description: Theatre was created in ancient Greece as a way to stage a dramatic performance.

6C76DF5633E84C7EA72F3FA214810D69.description: Experiences with drama can include learning about drama from the past and the people who created and performed plays.

667654F75763469C959DC8151282F378.description: Students examine culture through First Nations, M�tis, and Inuit drama and storytelling

3643C096A50841DE98875345CF0437DA.description:
Students investigate culture in relation to drama from ancient Greece and
present day.

D0E82DF72501438D8CCCF64440B54F9F.description: Appreciation: Recognizing beauty, goodness, and truth in drama can be developed by understanding the complexity and richness of great dramatic works, the artists who create and perform them, and the historical and cultural contexts from which they originate

06BA2023735E475388B951C481822F75.description: Apply creative processes to develop a message within dramatic play.

B7F4876CDC794918A374A42E123BBE86.description: Use improvisation to communicate a message.

0E0A17D091694C25BF648FFDBD227D16.description: Experiment with dramatic forms to express a message individually and with others

5AFE20CFE84144CDBBDCC58D71CD0A67.description: Creative processes can include practice generating an idea receiving feedback reflection

A9B0427585F0491491E3433C0107E40B.description: Expectations for participating in drama, known as artistic protocols and etiquette, can change depending on the context in which the dramatic work is experienced.

7A65AE69C1D14B578117F9BA56D69113.description: Empathy and perspectives can be gained through creating, viewing, and performing.

8E68C52E40994DD29173F62837C3ED10.description: Structure in dramatic play can help an audience know when the dramatic expression begins and ends.

9C16EC73A68C4D91A0B17B6FD7D95E0C.description: A message in drama can be generated, sent, received, and interpreted.

B49C2F87D3674FC29A0A9A3AF51A2BAA.description: Students experiment with how messages can be expressed through the body using dramatic play.

6D17E6D1DFA248CC953C8F769CE5855A.description: Creating and Presenting: Ideas can be represented dramatically through artworks that draw upon foundational knowledge

729827A0B6AD487BA9AEF365E1D3BD71.description: Explore how play can be used to demonstrate knowledge in other areas of learning.

504EF57EA64F498CABBA042FDA3B315D.description: Discuss how play can develop awareness of others' feelings or perspectives

9D616EAFDAA04E86BF2AF20F9BE3BB4E.description: Explore and discuss how everyday objects can be used symbolically within drama activities.

B3DC1D55988C4A8C98AF4E30B5269F5D.description: The body, as a dramatic tool, needs exercise to be healthy and flexible

3F3E06D97A2D478095A0EA2AEA47DCCA.description: The body is emotionally sensitive and is supported when drama experiences foster collaboration and trust.

15F2FB75D186436482A1DC7933EBF236.description: Imitation can be a method for exploring how the body can reproduce movement and vocal sounds in the development of a character

C3EE27244D574CC7940D246BEB503AEB.description: Character can be represented through the body.

8BA94A73979B456C9D938D3B242D5247.description: Where and how the body moves contributes to expression

BA6D2DE2510549F5951C1DC4F9945B62.description: The body communicates when still or moving.

2D17589191DB4DAE93033DFBE287E758.description: Dramatic play requires listening to understand one another

119940A033274CFFAFCEC9957C451089.description: Dramatic play can include rules that foster collaboration and trust.

CB1A84A193084B3CA11E781631D44614.description: Play can support demonstration of knowledge in other areas of learning through creative expression, including creative movement singing storytelling make-believe

E7D472642B9C4F2389DF85E1916BC39D.description: Dramatic play allows participants to experience other perspectives when exploring roles, characters, and situations.

1D574B28609746D3AA3E9C363DDF00D1.description: Play can contribute to an individual's wellbeing through the development of confidence, resiliency, and motivation.

36EAFA6C05B84FBD94279248827624E2.description: Play can foster symbolic thinking by using tools and materials in different ways to represent an object or idea.

AA109135EBDD4DAABA1CC4E3A7B93E75.description: Tableau is a dramatic form that utilizes the body to create still images

E9BDEBD7B79343FC913DEBFF01302056.description: Dramatic forms can give structure to dramatic play, including choral speech, puppetry, and tableau

85A7A5AEFA304A71AB0EA08C993F611A.description: Dramatic play can be based upon fictional or non-fictional characters, events, and situations.

97169A3187DA475A9CDA38D69B368C68.description: Students relate play and the body as a means to understand dramatic process.

7F6B1E15A9FD4864BBEE602CD45C28B1.description: Foundational Elements: Drama literacy is developed through knowledge and application of dramatic processes.
